messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help with Kanteisho
messages.msgSnippet: 1. Ichi, Henka-gata sukashi tsuba mumei Akao (item, unsigned  flower-shaped Akao tsuba) 2. Mokko-gata, tetsu-ji, sukashi-bori (four-lobed[quince shaped], iron
messages.messageBody:
1. Ichi, Henka-gata sukashi tsuba mumei Akao
(item, unsigned flower-shaped Akao tsuba)
2. Mokko-gata, tetsu-ji, sukashi-bori
(four-lobed[quince shaped], iron plate, pierced carving)
3. Edo jidai
(nuff said)
4. Migi wo Bunka Shiryo Tosogu to nintei suru
(The item listed at the right, is hereby recognized as Bunka Shiryo
Tosogu)
5. Heisei ju nen ni gatsu ni-ju hachi nichi
(February, 28th 1998)
6.Nihon Tosogu Bijutsukan, kancho Ikeda Suematsu
("signed" Director of the Nihon Tosogu Bijutsukan, Ikeda Suematsu)

Surfing the net a bit, we found that in Botany a natural mutation in a
flower is known as Henka. Morning Glories (Asagao) often exhibit
natural mutations and are called Henka-Asagao. Henge is another reading
and can mean goblin or ghost. So you could go with "strange-flower"
tsuba, or "Bugbear-tsuba" but I like "Mutant-tsuba!"
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help with Kanteisho
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Tom, thanks for that, I have the description sorted ( though I am unclear if that is what this paper says ) but it appears to be a Double nestled Mokko in
messages.messageBody:
Hi Tom, thanks for that, I have the description sorted ( though I am
unclear if that is what this paper says ) but it appears to be a Double
nestled Mokko in Ji Sukashi, thanks to the NCJSC mag ( issue June 2004,
Plate 97/194 ) and the Tôban Shinpin Zukan ( plate 97/194 ) I also have
put up a pic of the tsuba and the page from the Tôban Shinpin Zukan
http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/akao1.jpg

So it is now the row ( row 4 ) between the design and school, and the
Jidai that I don't have, and row 6, the level of the paper.

Cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help with Kanteisho
messages.msgSnippet: Rich et al- Not sure what it means but my kanji dictionary says this is read HENKA-gata , I think strange or oddball flower shape is as close as we may get.
messages.messageBody:
Rich et al-
Not sure what it means but my kanji dictionary says this is read
"HENKA-gata", I think strange or oddball flower shape is as close as we
may get. Henka alone means transformation, in Buddhism it is used when
the Buddha changes form to appear as a man, but don't think this
applies here...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help with Kanteisho
messages.msgSnippet: Yes, it s bunka shiryo tosogu.  The 3rd-6th kanji in that column read bunka shiryo (after migi wo). The 1st col. to the left of kanteisho says henbana gata
messages.messageBody:
Yes, it's bunka shiryo tosogu. The 3rd-6th kanji in that column read bunka shiryo (after migi wo).

The 1st col. to the left of "kanteisho" says henbana gata tsuba mumei Akao. The next col. to the left (smaller writing) is mokko gata tetsu ji sukashibori. Next (in parenthesis) is as you said Edo jidai.

Henbana is literally strange flower. I don't find a actual plant with that name, does anyone know of one? If not, then I guess it means what it says, strange flower shape.

Jim



All, I have a NTB Kanteisho for an Akao guard, and I am assuming it is
Bunka Shiryo^ or a "Cultural Item"

Is that mentioned in the 3rd last row from the left ?. I have the basic
stuff on this paper translated but the description, then I see Mumei
Akao, then something else, then Edo Jidai, the genuine something or
another, then the date, organizations seal etc..

Any help would be appreciated.

http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/pics/tsuba/Akao-kanteisho.jpg

>five elements and the five realms and I would have to go to my
>references for further info. This looks early to my eye but there are
>earlier on which this was clearly based. I feel certain though that

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba id
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Tom and Rich, Thanks for the opinions... consensus is that it is an old and good piece then? Iron tsuba make my head spin. She just sent me the scan and
messages.messageBody:
Hi Tom and Rich,

Thanks for the opinions... consensus is that it is an old and good piece then?

Iron tsuba make my head spin. She just sent me the scan and asked me to tell her
what it was, and I have no idea so I sent to the list.

If anyone else out there has opinions on age and if it should be submitted to
papers, I would like to know. My friend inherited a collection of tsuba at one
time so these mystery pieces pop up every now and then.

- darcy

> It is unfortunately upside down. You are looking at two stupa, stone
> "towers", often used as grave markers. The five pieces represent the
> five elements and the five realms and I would have to go to my
> references for further info. This looks early to my eye but there are
> earlier on which this was clearly based. I feel certain though that
> these are the stone towers and not the wooden grave markers which take
> a similar but thinner and even more elongated form...
> -t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba id
messages.msgSnippet: Nice piece- It is unfortunately upside down. You are looking at two stupa, stone towers , often used as grave markers. The five pieces represent the five
messages.messageBody:
Nice piece-
It is unfortunately upside down. You are looking at two stupa, stone
"towers", often used as grave markers. The five pieces represent the
five elements and the five realms and I would have to go to my
references for further info. This looks early to my eye but there are
earlier on which this was clearly based. I feel certain though that
these are the stone towers and not the wooden grave markers which take
a similar but thinner and even more elongated form...
-t

messages.msgSnippet: Just out of curiosity, is that the intended way of the steel ?  I can t help but think of fire scale, but I may be way off.  Interesting piece.  Also is
messages.messageBody:
Just out of curiosity, is that the intended "way of
the steel"? I can't help but think of fire scale, but
I may be way off. Interesting piece. Also is picture
upside down or is it intended to mount tachi style?
At this viewpoint I do get the impression of chimes.
Ken

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba id
messages.msgSnippet: Cool, it is reminiscent of a Katchûshi guard dated to the Kamakura period that is in Tsuba Kanshoki ( page 18 ) It looks like a Buddhist theme, maybe bells or
messages.messageBody:
Cool, it is reminiscent of a Katchûshi guard dated to the Kamakura
period that is in Tsuba Kanshoki ( page 18 ) It looks like a Buddhist
theme, maybe bells or chimes ??? or maybe there wooden tables as they
are in the sample in Tsuba Kanshoki. There appear to be kanji chiseled
into the thickest parts of the bells/tablets, is that correct ?.

Rich Turner
